content:
Posted: April 5
 Portal 2	 Pros: + Longer game+ More changeling puzzles that are at a good difficultly level+ More dialogue+ Better story compared to the first one+ Better ending compared to the first one+ Get on sale for a great price+ Learn more lore of the Portal world Cons: -  Still no cake	- Some puzzles will make you dumb- Middle drags on for sometime without any dialogue Review Portal 2 brings back what you love from the first Portal and improves on many other areas. After playing the first Portal relatively quickly, I started up Portal 2 and sat down thinking it would be as short as the first one. I was wrong, this game has much more meat than the first Portal. It was fun to shoot portals across large areas and teleport across them. What I loved about Portal 1 and Portal 2 is that it all can be done without a walkthrough, but it's not easy either. It has an interesting start and a legendary ending. The middle part wasn't that amazing, but it wasn't bad either. All in all, I am happy that I finally played the two Portal games, and even though I am not a huge fan of puzzle games it was still enjoyable. It is a great buy when it's on sale.This was Curated for PC Beta Gaming if you would like to follow us the link is below: http://steamcommunity.com/groups/PC-BetaG#curationIf you liked this review please give it a thumbs up. This review is just my opinion, and if you disliked it or thought I could have done something better please leave a comment. Thank you for reading my review. If you would like to see more of my reviews the link is below: http://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198120632907/recommended/?p=1

content:
Posted: February 7, 2013
												This is one of my favorite games of all time. A lot of you might think that the original Portal is better, but from what I've seen, it doesn't look any better than Portal 2. Then again, I haven't played it yet.The story of Portal 2 is simple. After what happens in Portal, you wake up in a room that you find out is a containment facility (like the original game, but more... roomy.) After being there for a really long time, your mental state has suffered a lot. However, because there is nobody taking care of Aperture science, the state of the laboratory has suffered as well. Your motives in Portal 2 constantly change, and the story takes many twists and turns while you're playing. This keeps the story fresh and entertaining as you progress, which is a great thing as the story of Portal 2 is important (mostly because of what happens in the first game.)Portal 2, for a game that came out in 2011, looks really polished and has a great visual atmosphere. You can see the effects your actions in the first game have caused in the first 10 minutes of the game, and it's a constant theme throughout the game. Like the story, the visual asthetic has many twists and turns, but key objects stay consistant. This gives you a clear direction of what to do in the game, while also giving you a fresh new canvas to look at.The gameplay in Portal 2 has been improved upon from Portal, not changed. Key features are the same, but new features give the game life and give people who loved the first game a reason to play through the second one. This game has a very megaman-esque feel when it comes to game mechanics. When a new mechanic is introduced, it's usually in an environment that is very lenient so you can learn how that mechanic works. Once the game feels you're ready, it gives you challenges that involve that game mechanic that get progressively harder. Even after beating this game 4 times, I still get stumped on some puzzles. THAT is good game design.All in all, Portal 2 is a masterpiece of a game. There is something for everyone in this game, and I fully recommend buying this at full price. Quick note, I haven't really touched Multiplayer or the level editor.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 2, 2014
												– The storyYou are set in the future where a Robot called GLaDOS is presented as a sarcastic nemesis who just won’t leave you alone. You first are introduced to a seemingly friendly floating robot head Wheatley. He takes you through a bunch of tests which GLaDOS is presenting you with while he tries to take over the place. What happens next You have to find out for yourself.– My thought’sThe game itself is a piece of Art. Everything about the game just screams yes. The game is about puzzles and thinking with portals. If you haven’t played the first portal that’s ok, I’ve played the first portal a long time ago and it didn’t impact the second game that much. Story mode of the game is done perfectly, voice acting as silly as it may in a robot game is done very well + animations are great. Maybe the only way it would be improved if you could play co-op with more people, other than that it’s perfect. I personally like the introductions of the Portal gun. Co-op was executed as good as you can possibly execute it, I was stunned to see how well the Multiplayer was made. A lot of games don’t have a good co-op system and/or multiplayer, but Portal 2 just took made it as easy as possible. If you wish to play co-op I suggest finishing singleplayer beforehand. Co-op doesn’t include a story, but rather multiple puzzles for you and your friend. I honestly can’t find anything bad to say about this game because it is just perfect, little to no bugs at all.– The summaryThe game is excellent for people who wan’t to challenge themselves and friends.– The Pros+ Story – The game has an excellent story mode for you to complete.+ Co-op – This game includes a co-op mode for you and your friends to play, and can be set up in a matter seconds.+ Smooth graphics – The graphics of the game are just stunning and perform well even for not so good computers.+ Little to no Bugs – In my time of gameplay I didn’t experience any bug at all.+ Community workshop – When I found out I could play other people’s creations I was just sucked even more into the game then before.+ Level editor – Another option the game allows is a custom editor for you to make your own maps and creations and share with the world.+ Independant game – What I mean by this is, even if you haven’t played the first portal game you don’t need to because the game’s story mode isn’t affected by the other game.– The Cons+ Short ending – To be honest this is the only thing I could put on this, it doesn’t even deserve a “The bad” section because it was so darn good.+ Micro-Transactions – The only way to customize your character within the game is to spend a few bucks on a skin.– The rating + I would rate the game a solid 9/10 just because of the performance and everything about it. Definitely suggest this game to your more puzzle-loving friends.

												– The storyYou are set in the future where a Robot called GLaDOS is presented as a sarcastic nemesis who just won’t leave you alone. You first are introduced to a seemingly friendly floating robot head Wheatley. He takes you through a bunch of tests which GLaDOS is presenting you with while he tries to take over the place. What happens next You have to find out for yourself.– My thought’sThe game itself is a piece of Art. Everything about the game just screams yes. The game is about puzzles and thinking with portals. If you haven’t played the first portal that’s ok, I’ve played the first portal a long time ago and it didn’t impact the second game that much. Story mode of the game is done perfectly, voice acting as silly as it may in a robot game is done very well + animations are great. Maybe the only way it would be improved if you could play co-op with more people, other than that it’s perfect. I personally like the introductions of the Portal gun. Co-op was executed as good as you can possibly execute it, I was stunned to see how well the Multiplayer was made. A lot of games don’t have a good co-op system and/or multiplayer, but Portal 2 just took made it as easy as possible. If you wish to play co-op I suggest finishing singleplayer beforehand. Co-op doesn’t include a story, but rather multiple puzzles for you and your friend. I honestly can’t find anything bad to say about this game because it is just perfect, little to no bugs at all.– The summaryThe game is excellent for people who wan’t to challenge themselves and friends.– The Pros+ Story – The game has an excellent story mode for you to complete.+ Co-op – This game includes a co-op mode for you and your friends to play, and can be set up in a matter seconds.+ Smooth graphics – The graphics of the game are just stunning and perform well even for not so good computers.+ Little to no Bugs – In my time of gameplay I didn’t experience any bug at all.+ Community workshop – When I found out I could play other people’s creations I was just sucked even more into the game then before.+ Level editor – Another option the game allows is a custom editor for you to make your own maps and creations and share with the world.+ Independant game – What I mean by this is, even if you haven’t played the first portal game you don’t need to because the game’s story mode isn’t affected by the other game.– The Cons+ Short ending – To be honest this is the only thing I could put on this, it doesn’t even deserve a “The bad” section because it was so darn good.+ Micro-Transactions – The only way to customize your character within the game is to spend a few bucks on a skin.– The rating + I would rate the game a solid 9/10 just because of the performance and everything about it. Definitely suggest this game to your more puzzle-loving friends.

content:
Posted: January 4, 2014
												Portal 2 follows up with the same game mechanics as Portal but this time adds in a full single player campaign. Once you're done with single player there is another lengthy co-op campaign, and once you're done with that there are a few bonus co-op DLC levels included called Art Therapy. This game gets you scratching your head on how to solve complex puzzles but starts off with simple puzzles so you can get used to the mechanics and various game elements. Highly recommended, and nothing beats the feeling you get once you solve a chamber that has been stumping you for awhile. Lastly, thanks to the Steam Workshop there are an infinite amount of community made chambers waiting for you.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 15, 2013
												Who'd have thought that such a simple concept could be so complex and intricate? Portal is like a modern day equivalent of chess, but with a portal gun, no board and no pieces. So, entirely nothing like chess then... There is the similarity of having to think several steps ahead though, so that malformed chess comparison might be of some merit after all. There's no story in chess either, unless you've made you're own narrative up, involving the queen running off with the bishop to a rook on the back of a knight. If so, then perhaps you should seek help."Taking a trip down the Funnel of Death."So, the patented Aperture Science portal gun is back once again, and if you thought some of Portal's test chambers were convoluted, then you're in for a rude awakening with Portal 2, as there are some real brain-melting doozies awaiting in the numerous test chambers of Aperture Laboratories. Portal 1 feels like it was a dry run for this, the main event, which not only tells a killer story with more twists and turns than an Excursion Funnel (more on those later), but it takes the core portal concept and throws in a whole load of new mind-bending mechanics.What follows is a blend of frustration, puzzlement, bewilderment and thankfully, a hefty dose of jubilation. You see, nothing beats the feeling of satisfaction upon solving one of Portal 2's expertly engineered tests, amid the taunts and barbs being dispensed by omnipotent AI, GLaDOS, who is back with a vengeance for the sequel. With the addition of Repulsion Gel, Propulsion Gel, Conversion Gel, Faith Plates, Hard Light Bridges and Excursion Funnels, Portal 2 kicks things up several notches, creating some of the most fiendish head-scratchers you're ever likely to come across.At certain junctures, we'd become seemingly, insurmountably stuck and curse the game design, the level design and everything while trying to formulate a solution to a particular obstacle or what appears to be a total impasse. Moments like these are hugely frustrating, essentially because they make you feel stupid for not being able to get into the right mindset. And after that complete feeling of hopelessness at your own cognitive shortcomings, the reward of a 'eureka' moment, when the solution is suddenly right there in front of you, is entirely worth it."Atlas and P-body are proper endearing, innit?"Of course, there is a lot to learn in Portal 2, but Valve pitches the learning curve perfectly, slowly easing you into the various mechanics, gently laying things out for you so it all makes sense, even if you missed playing the first Portal. Things start off nice and simple then, once returning protagonist Chell experiences her rude awakening, and before you know it, you're back in the clean-walled confines of the Aperture Laboratories ready to be taunted and cajoled through increasingly testing experiments. Soon, you'll come across blue Repulsion Gel that enables you to bounce off any surfaces painted in the stuff, orange Propulsion Gel that speeds up your running speed and white Conversion Gel that enables you to project portals on it. Then the game throws Excursion Funnels into the mix, which enable you to float through the air to otherwise inaccessible plateaus, and it's combining all of these elements that makes Portal 2 so immensely and gratifyingly challenging.And for a while, you'll be prodded from test chamber to test chamber, bending to GlaDOS's every whim, until everything predictably goes horribly awry. To say any more would be a horrible spoiler, but suffice to say that Valve has crafted a narrative that really does have it all. It's funny, dark and tense in equal measure, as well as consistently entertaining from start to finish.It's the gameplay that really makes Portal 2 such a joy though and everything else is just the icing on the... - we had to say it at some point – cake. That's before you even consider co-op, which is a whole separate campaign on its own, starring the most endearing droid duo since C3PO and R2D2. Playable in local split screen – vertical or horizontal: your call – or online with a friend or a random, Portal 2's co-op is pure genius, encouraging communication and actual, proper co-ordination. Playing without a headset really isn't an option, despite being able to project markers and start countdowns via the in-game HUD, and playing with someone you don't know proves remarkably difficult, if not nigh-on impossible. Even Valve knows this, as it even thought to include a warning disclaimer telling you that the game won't be as fun if you try and play with a person not on your friends list."We don't think BP is to blame for this one."Get an actual friend to play with you though, and you'll find that tearing through all five Courses of test chambers is a blast, with Atlas and P-body high-fiving and dancing their way through even more slickly designed stages that deal with each specific game mechanic Course by Course. It's enormous fun to hit Portal 2 in co-op and being given four portals to play with rather than two puts a whole different spin on the game's basic mechanics. In fact, we can't remember the last time we played a co-op title like this, that required constant communication between the two-players in order to beat each puzzle. Be forewarned though, you may need a large TV screen to get the best out of playing co-op in split screen. Online however, it all works brilliantly.Portal 2 continues a great tradition of clever and inventive achievement lists concocted by Valve, rewarding exploration with a few Easter eggs, including a few hidden surprises that shed light on certain aspects of the Aperture Science story. There's an excellent balance between single-player and co-op achievements too, making playing both modes even more essential. Most achievements are attained through natural progression, but there might be a few you miss along the way. Luckily, upon completing both the single-player and co-op facets of the Portal 2 story, you're able to jump back into any of the chapters. This is done via the hub in co-op, where you can also mess around gesturing and playing rock, paper, scissors to your heart's content. All in all, Portal 2's achievement list is excellent then.A riveting journey from start to finish, Portal 2 is yet another unmitigated triumph for Valve, building upon an original concept that was incredible to begin with and making it even more incredible. At times it might have you tearing your hair out, but ultimately if you loved Portal 1 (and who didn't?), you're going to eat up Portal 2 like a big old piece of vanilla crazy cake.

content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
												I really love this game.I am a person who really likes difficult puzzle games, especially ones with nice story and dialog.Portal 2 I found to be too easy though. It wasn't as challenging as I wanted. I like the humor and dialog a lot though. Weatley and GlaDOS are pretty meniaclly hilarious. I liked Portal 1 better because the voice of GlaDOS was a little more robotic and believeable, and the puzzles were a little tougher.I liked Portal 2 because it was longer, and there was more to it. Overall it is a great game, good music, great visuals, and voice acting, and at times has challenging puzzles. You should play it as well as Portal 1.The thing that keeps me coming back time and again to this game is the community created content called Community Chambers. You can download test chambers made by members of the community for both Co-Op and Solo. You can also create test chambers of your own just using the vanilla game. I LOVE that feature. It gives the game INFINITE replayability. Some of the maps that people make can be really tough too, and I like that. You can continue to play maps made by the community, and there will always be more than you can even play because people keep making them.That is the main reason why I got this game for Steam when I already had it for Xbox360. On Xbox you cannot play community content or make your own maps. Even if you have this game for console you should try it on steam for community chambers. I highly recommend it. You can play chambers for hours.Buy it for INFINITE replayability!

Posted: September 22, 2013
												Portal 2... the game people have been demanding since the world was lit with light. The masterpiece that fills your eyes with tears of joy... that cake.... It's undeniably a game you would want to grasp as soon as possible; embrace the companion cube, learn the truth about cake... umm... friendship. If one portal wasn't enough, then two is more than you could ever imagine. You won't be needing anything else! Take 2 pay for 1, they come in two colors, have a nice day! But that's not it! If you order as we speak, you'll get a free potato and a lemon! Hold your horses... let's double that offer! You will now get two potatoes and two lemons! You must think we just cloned that deal using a cloning machine, but fear not... we keep our minds inside the safe zone at all times.As the boss says: "When you give up, that's when you truly *bleep* up." Reach beyond your imagination, befriend the repair robot, color everything with experimental gels, reveal the lie as it unfolds itself.... Get it now![Rejected sale attempt #108 - Aperture Science]

content:
Posted: March 18, 2016
												Portal 2 is a first-person perspective puzzle game. The Player takes the role of Chell in the single-player campaign, as one of two robots—Atlas and P-Body—in the cooperative campaign, or as a simplistic humanoid icon in community-developed puzzles. These four characters can explore and interact with the environment. Characters can withstand limited damage but will die after sustained injury. There is no penalty for falling onto a solid surface, but falling into bottomless pits or toxic pools kills the player character immediately. When Chell dies in the single-player game, the game restarts from a recent checkpoint;in the cooperative game, the robot respawns shortly afterwards without restarting the puzzle.The goal of both campaigns is to explore the Aperture Science Laboratory—a complicated, malleable mechanized maze. While most of the game takes place in modular test chambers with clearly defined entrances and exits, other parts occur in behind-the-scenes areas where the objective is less clear.The initial tutorial levels guide the player through the general movement controls and illustrate how to interact with the environment. The player must solve puzzles using the 'portal gun' or 'Aperture Science Handheld Portal Device', which can create two portals connecting two distant surfaces depicted as matte white, continuous, and flat. Characters can use these portals to move between rooms or to "fling" objects or themselves across a distance. Outlines of placed portals are visible through walls and other obstacles for easy location.Game elements include Thermal Discouragement Beams (lasers), Excursion Funnels (tractor beams), and Hard Light Bridges, all of which can be transmitted through portals.Aerial Faith Plates launch the player or objects through the air and sometimes into portals. The player must disable turrets or avoid their line of sight. The Weighted Storage Cube has been redesigned, and there are new types: Redirection Cubes, which have prismatic lenses that redirect laser beams, spherical Edgeless Safety Cubes, an antique version of the Weighted Storage Cube used in the underground levels, and a cube-turret hybrid created by Wheatley after taking control of Aperture.The heart-decorated Weighted Companion Cube reappears briefly.Early demonstrations included Pneumatic Diversity Vents, shown to transport objects and transfer suction power through portals, but these do not appear in the final game.All of these game elements open locked doors, or help or hamper the character from reaching the exit.Paint-like gels (which are dispensed from pipes and can be transported through portals) impart certain properties to surfaces or objects coated with them.Players can use orange Propulsion Gel to cross surfaces more quickly, blue Repulsion Gel to bounce from a surface,and white Conversion Gel to allow surfaces to accept portals.Only one type of gel can be effective on a certain surface at a time only. Some surfaces, such as grilles, cannot be coated with a gel. Water can block or wash away gels, returning the surface or object to its normal state.The game includes a two-player cooperative mode.Two players can use the same console with a split screen, or can use a separate computer or console; Microsoft Windows, Mac OS X, and PlayStation 3 users can play with each other regardless of platform; a patch provided in late 2012 added split-screen support for Windows and Mac OS X users under "Big Picture" mode.Both player-characters are robots that control separate portal guns and can use the other character's portals.Each player's portals are of a different color scheme, whereof one is blue and purple and the other is orange and red.A calibration chamber separates the characters to teach the players to use the communication tools and portals. Most later chambers are less structured and require players to use both sets of portals for laser or funnel redirection, launches, and other maneuvers.The game provides voice communication between players, and online players can temporarily enter a split-screen view to help coordinate actions.Players can "ping" to draw the other player's attention to walls or objects, start countdown timers for synchronized actions, and perform joint gestures such as waving or hugging.The game tracks which chambers each player has completed and allows players to replay chambers they have completed with new partners.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 2, 2015
												I find so hard to believe how *well made* this game is. I passed Portal three times (but I've got a total of 9hrs, not much at all)  and thoroughly enjoyed it; mostly because it's inside the Half-Life universe. I had been wanting to play Portal 2 for a very long time because of it, since the first game was so original and well thought-out. I actually memorised most of the Portal levels and tricks, so I thought Portal 2 wouldn't be a huge challenge, and that it'd be easier. I thought it wouldn't make me think as much as the first game, I was sure of it. And I was wrong.Valve has crafted something astounding with Portal 2. There were about four chambers in which I was so frustrated I just wanted to rip the hair off my skull. The game forced me to think and puzzled me a great deal. When I wasn't stressing myself, shooting portals all over the map and jumping to my death in exasperation every ten seconds, I was astounded and unable to believe how incredibly well made the maps are and how well executed the chambers are. Portal isn't my favourite Valve game, subjectively to me it isn't the best. But objectively, I have to say Portal is Valve's best creation. They have crafted something special in this game, three influential factors (two which I'll count as one): Humour, tragedy/darkness and originality. The first factor is evident. Cave Johnson and his speeches are hilarious. GlaDOS is a ♥♥♥♥♥, and yet her intended-to-be-hurtful comments are hilarious and found a way to make me gasp in both surprise and humour. The long-fall boots, turret trailer and the Portal Valentine's Day video are hilarious to say the very least (and freaking original!).The second factor is well covered up by the first factor, but it is still there nevertheless. Portal has a tragic story: that is undeniable. Aperture Laboratories has a tragic, screwed-up background. Test subjects were treated like dirt, the scientists didn't care an iota about their welfare and Cave Johnson didn't even try to hide his contempt towards them. That's why it's screwed-up, but it's tragic because it's an abandoned facility which used to be one of the greatest science companies of all time (even though they had their fair share of controversies) and it wasn't abandoned because of its bankrupcy, or because they ran out of ideas/products. It's because everyone was murdered, dammit! Every single scientist we know of, except Rattman, is dead and just when Aperture had its most promising project under its sleeve. Not a single soul is seen in Aperture; death is such a strong essence in Portal but the tragedy is well masqueraded by the undeniable humour. The third and last factor is the most astonishing one: ORIGINALITY. The test chambers, the idea of the game, the execution of physics in the game to make a realistic notion out of the puzzle-solving with the Handheld Portal Device; as bizarre as the idea of a gun which shoots portals in plain surfaces sounds, Valve found a way to make it seem both believable and realistic. Both with the execution of physics in the game and with the explanation of the gun itself. It's incredible. These three factors, but the last one specially, is why I consider Portal is the best game Valve has ever made, and why I consider it to be one of the most amazing games to *ever* be created. I recommend it to *everyone*.Thank you Lord Gaben for hiring the folks at Nuclear Monkey Software to create this franchise. PRAISE GABEN!

content:
Posted: July 17, 2014
												The cake is a lie, but the Portal games certainly take it as my favorite puzzle games of all time. I've actually played this game on console, and played through both the solo and co-op campaigns multiple times. This is the sequel that Portal deserved for a couple of reasons:First off, the story falls right in line with the first game. It's in depth, and builds heavily around a tight group of fully fleshed out characters.Secondly I'd like to bring up gameplay. Just like the first one, no corners were cut with the physics in this game. The fact that the player can move so smoothly through the wide open test chambers makes the visuals that much more enjoyable, because there really are a number of awe-inspiring scenes.Lastly I'd like to note why I bought this game a second time when I'd already played a considerable amount of it on console. I bought it for the community contributions and map editor. Playing fan-made solo and co-op maps are often more fun and more thought provoking than the actual puzzles in the game. The ability just to mess around in the map creator (with an EXTREMELY intuitive interface none-the-less) justified my second purchase of the game.One of my favorite games of all time.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 24, 2014
												"I DON'T NEED YOUR DAMN LEMONS."One of the many great quotes that come from this jewel of a game. After having already played Half-Life 1 when I was 6 and Half-Life 2 the many unbearable years later, I can say that Valve is one of my favorite game developers, and Portal is a game that justifies that dignity. The concept of Portal itself is already exotic in itself. Valve takes this notion and flawlessly creates a game that tackles you with numerous labyrinths along with a tasteful and humorous storyline that grasps your attention to continue on. Even though this game is a puzzle game, a genre that usually can't attract interest like other popular ones today, this game is an exception. One can become easily attached to the eccentric characters of the story, from the cynical ones to the ones that just scream 1 elongated word in space. I've played this game 3 times already and have yet to be tired of it. You'd think I would memorize the puzzles by the second run, but some of them still manage to escape my mind, and I find myself overthinking or overlooking something. The puzzles are flawless and their carefully and meticulously creators made sure that there were no loopholes nor errors. The level creator even allows more hours for endless creativity and fun. Of course, my puzzles are complete crap and have loopholes ever. Easily one of my most favorite games of all time. Get it.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 27, 2014
												Edit, wanted to rewrite this whole review. Portal 2 is the only reason I got back into gaming. I was at a school center, and I saw the place had a COMPUTER LAB, that also had PS3's and 360's. I was pretty happy. At the time, all I played was Minecraft. I used to play my Nintendo DS and DSi and my Gameboy, but I grew out of them. Usually the computers were taken by people playing Minecraft, so I sat myself down at a 360, and I checked under the counter for games. There it was. Portal 2. I played that game so much. Need for Speed: Most Wanted reeled me in to deciding that I wanted a PS3. I got a PS3 with Most Wanted and Portal 2 and other games. I was so happy. One day, I checked the inside and saw there was a code for a free copy on Steam. I remembered that I made a Steam a year ago because my friend told me to, but I never used it! I was happy because you needed a retail or Steam purchase to unlock all Steam features. I started to build my Steam collection from there, and I started an obsession over ALL Valve games, especially Counter Strike and Half Life. Portal 2 is sincerely my favorite game ever.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 27, 2015
												This game is literally the most incredible puzzle game you will ever play. Brilliant and orignal Sci-Fi Dystopian story with a nice dark tone set in the Half-Life universe. Challenging and well-thought-out puzzles that progressively change with more and more features. A puzzle game that still manages to make combat an epic puzzle on it's own. Graphics are good for its time (4 years ago now). Voice acting is superb and the music is incredibly well-done. Throw in multiplayer and the capability for custom chambers and you have a the single highest rated game on Steam. Seriously, buy this game. Get your friends to buy this game. Do it. I literally have no negatives for it.500/10

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 22, 2014
												This game, is incredible. The gameplay is nearly flawless, and the idea is brilliant. But first let me addresss everything the naysayers about this game say. 1: Predictable storyline. Hmmmmmmmmmmm I would agree with you there... except you didn't play the whole game. Seriously, almost everyone who says this has not played the whole game. And for the few who did, you clearly did not watch your surroundings enough. The point of the story was to make you want to play more, and it certainly did well on that note. 2: Not very hard. Again, play the whole game first. True, the game was not THAT hard, but I cannot think of a  puzzle game that executes the gameplay as well as portal does. While the game itself was not terribly hard, the community has certainly made some head scratching test chambers that will make you want to eat your own words. 3: Crashes. The game does not crash anymore (except on windows 8 so far) so ignore those reviewers who say that because their review is now irrelevent. Final score 9/10

content:
Posted: March 28, 2015
												GREAT GAME, had lots of fun playing it. Awesome physics and mechanics, great levels designs and gameplay. Didn't stay stuck for too long on any stage which made the game enven more enjoyable. Something that I really enjoy was the humor and the sarcasm in every scene (well done). There is only one down-side to the game: it is quite short (beated the co-op and single player in about 15h), but that is understandable, due to the fact that such great effort went to making every stage. I highly recommand this game, more specifically to people who love platformers and strategy game. I don't regret anything about this purchase, a couple of nights (even days) of fun. Once again, GREAT GAME.

content:
Posted: January 27, 2014
												Edit, wanted to rewrite this whole review. Portal 2 is the only reason I got back into gaming. I was at a school center, and I saw the place had a COMPUTER LAB, that also had PS3's and 360's. I was pretty happy. At the time, all I played was Minecraft. I used to play my Nintendo DS and DSi and my Gameboy, but I grew out of them. Usually the computers were taken by people playing Minecraft, so I sat myself down at a 360, and I checked under the counter for games. There it was. Portal 2. I played that game so much. Need for Speed: Most Wanted reeled me in to deciding that I wanted a PS3. I got a PS3 with Most Wanted and Portal 2 and other games. I was so happy. One day, I checked the inside and saw there was a code for a free copy on Steam. I remembered that I made a Steam a year ago because my friend told me to, but I never used it! I was happy because you needed a retail or Steam purchase to unlock all Steam features. I started to build my Steam collection from there, and I started an obsession over ALL Valve games, especially Counter Strike and Half Life. Portal 2 is sincerely my favorite game ever.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2015
												One of the best games you'll ever play, I guarantee it.Portal 2 has two great different game modes: Singleplayer and Co-Op. Sadly, if you don't have any friends, you won't be able to play the co-op, but in my opinion, the singleplayer alone would be worth your money.Your problem solving skills will come to a test while playing this, but the story alone in this game is something to love; Portal 2 is a perfect example of great narration and character interaction with the player. The characters are enjoyable and the gameplay is easy enough to master. You can explore and find easter eggs that tell you more about the plot and the world you're in.The co-op is also entertaining. Puzzles that you have to solve with a friend? Nothing could be more fun! The commands help communication alot - you can watch your friend in a small window to see what he sees, and with the easy commands you can tell your friend what to do. You practically don't need voice chat at all, but it does help alot! The puzzles in the game are fun as well, as the small storyline that goes along with the co-op - nothing major, but still enjoyable. And the community maps are endless - you can always get more community made maps, that can be wonderful to play through!TL;DR: 10/10, would play again. Must buy game if on sale in Steam!You can also have a drinking game with a friend, if one of you fails, take a shot. You'll get hammered in no time, because mistakes are bound to happen.

content:
Posted: July 2, 2015
												Valve takes the show again with this outstanding follow up to the indie puzzle game "Portal". Portal 2 manages to be clever, funny, innovative and immersive. The game creates a story you'll never forget however it is fairly short. A seasoned player can complete both the story and co-op story in about 8 hours, but on a first time through it takes about 15-20 minutes. It isn't your average game, but if you buy it I can promise you won't be sorry

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 27, 2014
												Portal 2 is the succsessor to the original Portal, and is still very good. You are in a room waiting to be tested at Aperture, and you sleep. You awake many years later, to find that that Aperture has degraded a lot because of no maintanence, and you move along thanks to the core, Wheatley. You revive GLaDOS, and off you go through the abandoned facility. Many of the things are wreaking with age, and there is even a part where you go down to the depths of the facility, where the older versions of the facility are (Aperture was much better during the 50s-80s than what it currently is. Seriously, this is fun. And there is a large community willing to make maps (thanks to the map edior), adding longetivity to the game.Final Score In Words: Get this game ASAP or die of boredom.

content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
												This is the beat game I've ever played!!!The main part of this game are a whole bunch of challenaging puzzles. They are not very difficult, but quite tricky and you will need some time to observe your surroundings and find out the solution. It will be a real challenge for your observation and imagination.I will also recommen you to play the co-op mode with your friend. You will need really good cooperation skills to make through it, and the tricks you use in co-op mode is fairly different from that you use in single mode.Finally, the story in this game is pretty dramatic and attrative. I enjoy the special perspective of A.I. on human and science, and I love the different personalities of different cores. (especially the yellow core who love space XD)Overall, Portal2 is a really great game that I would always recommend to my friends.10/10

												Portal 2 continues where the original left off, adding more puzzles and things to play with in this fun sequal.  While it isn't as groundbreaking as the first was, I don't think anything can be.Pros:More of the same fun as the originalMultiplayerUser-generated conted and maps to exploreCons:Just didn't "wow" me as much as the originalIt's hard to beat the groundbreaking Portal, and although this is a great game with a lot of Valve polish I would recommend anyone to play the first over the second in a heartbeat (unless they're playing with a friend).  B+

content:
Posted: July 24, 2014
												"I DON'T NEED YOUR DAMN LEMONS."One of the many great quotes that come from this jewel of a game. After having already played Half-Life 1 when I was 6 and Half-Life 2 the many unbearable years later, I can say that Valve is one of my favorite game developers, and Portal is a game that justifies that dignity. The concept of Portal itself is already exotic in itself. Valve takes this notion and flawlessly creates a game that tackles you with numerous labyrinths along with a tasteful and humorous storyline that grasps your attention to continue on. Even though this game is a puzzle game, a genre that usually can't attract interest like other popular ones today, this game is an exception. One can become easily attached to the eccentric characters of the story, from the cynical ones to the ones that just scream 1 elongated word in space. I've played this game 3 times already and have yet to be tired of it. You'd think I would memorize the puzzles by the second run, but some of them still manage to escape my mind, and I find myself overthinking or overlooking something. The puzzles are flawless and their carefully and meticulously creators made sure that there were no loopholes nor errors. The level creator even allows more hours for endless creativity and fun. Of course, my puzzles are complete crap and have loopholes ever. Easily one of my most favorite games of all time. Get it.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 17, 2014
												The cake is a lie, but the Portal games certainly take it as my favorite puzzle games of all time. I've actually played this game on console, and played through both the solo and co-op campaigns multiple times. This is the sequel that Portal deserved for a couple of reasons:First off, the story falls right in line with the first game. It's in depth, and builds heavily around a tight group of fully fleshed out characters.Secondly I'd like to bring up gameplay. Just like the first one, no corners were cut with the physics in this game. The fact that the player can move so smoothly through the wide open test chambers makes the visuals that much more enjoyable, because there really are a number of awe-inspiring scenes.Lastly I'd like to note why I bought this game a second time when I'd already played a considerable amount of it on console. I bought it for the community contributions and map editor. Playing fan-made solo and co-op maps are often more fun and more thought provoking than the actual puzzles in the game. The ability just to mess around in the map creator (with an EXTREMELY intuitive interface none-the-less) justified my second purchase of the game.One of my favorite games of all time.

You will need really good cooperation skills to make through it, and the tricks you use in co-op mode is fairly different from that you use in single mode.Finally, the story in this game is pretty dramatic and attrative. I enjoy the special perspective of A.I. on human and science, and I love the different personalities of different cores. (especially the yellow core who love space XD)Overall, Portal2 is a really great game that I would always recommend to my friends.10/10

												I've put over 110 hours into a game that has a 6 hour storyline. And that doesn't factor in the hours I put into it on my PS3. That should tell you something about how fun this game is. Between the writing of the characters, the level design, the voice work, and the concept of portals and addition of gels, this is the straight up funnest game I've ever played in my life. It's my go-to game for showing someone who "doesn't like video games" how much fun games can be. I can't imagine somebody playing this and not enjoying themselves.

												Portal 2 is a very good game.It's got a great storyline, amazing humor, pretty hard levels, and a whole lot of science.It's a Valve classic. Lots of features, such as co-op play and level creating!When I first got this game, I thought that Portal 2 would be pretty weird. Once I got into the second chapter, I was hooked. The puzzles were challenging and very clever. Once I finally beat the game, I played it again. And again. And again.All in all, this is one of my all time favorites.Storyline:You play as Chell, a test subject at Aperture Science. You have been held captive for many years. You now have to make your way through the abandoned ruins of Aperture with the Handheld Portal Device.Have fun with this game!

content:
Posted: January 15, 2015
												If someone were to ask me what my favourite game was, I'd say Portal 2. I have a handful of games that I hold dear to my heart, but Portal 2 is a gem. It basically took the BRILLIANT concept of Portal and expanded on it. They added quite a few new gameplay mechanics that interact with the portals (that will leave you scratching your head while having a blast messing around with everything), giving it that much more depth. The characters are just perfect. It's a wonderful balance of humour, banter between characters, intellect, sass..without it being too much. It never got annoying or felt like they were pushing a character too hard in an attempt to be funny. I honestly have a soft spot for all the characters and they just make me so happy. I get so immersed when playing, getting lost in the puzzles (that aren't too easy, aren't too hard), fantastic dialogue, and atmosphere (the scenery is incredible, the littlest details add to the overall dreary tone).I have beaten this game 7 times I believe, between xbox and an old steam account, and it was always as enjoyable as the time before. It has replay value if you give it 6 months inbetween playing sessions, you forget a lot of the solutions. I wouldn't get stuck often, but it wasn't an instant-robotic-motion of "ok I have to go here, then here, and now this", I still had to think. I found myself laughing at the  jokes and blunt ridicules towards one another, even after I'd played several times. Playing Portal 2 is just a wonderful, fun experience and I can't recommend it highly enough.Side note: If you enjoyed the single player Portal 2 campaign, you will enjoy multiplayer as well. Besides showing off how smart you are compared to the other person by figuring out the puzzles lickity split, you will feel all fuzzy inside when you kill them over and over. :)

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 24, 2015
												Portal 2 is easily one of the best games of this console generation. It's not quite as good as Portal, but it is definitely worth your time. The difference between Portal and Portal 2 is that Portal was a stellar puzzle game with a stellar framework, but Portal 2 is a story that begrudgingly has a puzle game in it. For example, the death mechanic here puts more time between you and what you were doing before. It's still a fantastic puzzle game, and new mechanics like gels and lasers form around the main portal mechanic like fluffed sugar around a stick in a cotton candy machine. And let me tell you, it's delicious cotton candy.

content:
Posted: April 22, 2014
												This game, is incredible. The gameplay is nearly flawless, and the idea is brilliant. But first let me addresss everything the naysayers about this game say. 1: Predictable storyline. Hmmmmmmmmmmm I would agree with you there... except you didn't play the whole game. Seriously, almost everyone who says this has not played the whole game. And for the few who did, you clearly did not watch your surroundings enough. The point of the story was to make you want to play more, and it certainly did well on that note. 2: Not very hard. Again, play the whole game first. True, the game was not THAT hard, but I cannot think of a  puzzle game that executes the gameplay as well as portal does. While the game itself was not terribly hard, the community has certainly made some head scratching test chambers that will make you want to eat your own words. 3: Crashes. The game does not crash anymore (except on windows 8 so far) so ignore those reviewers who say that because their review is now irrelevent. Final score 9/10

content:
Posted: December 3, 2013
												Do I really need to review Portal 2? Ok. As you can see, it's a sequel to the original Portal. The basics of the game are the same - you need to use portals to overcome different puzzles. In Portal 2 you have new mechanics(including different versions of cubes), you have new environment(like Aperture Labrotories from 50ties). Also you have co-op in Portal 2(it's a completly different campaing) and Steam Workshop support(which keeps this game alive - that's how I played 100 hours). Pick it up if you liked original or if you want some good action-puzzle game with great atmosphere.

Didn't stay stuck for too long on any stage which made the game enven more enjoyable. Something that I really enjoy was the humor and the sarcasm in every scene (well done). There is only one down-side to the game: it is quite short (beated the co-op and single player in about 15h), but that is understandable, due to the fact that such great effort went to making every stage. I highly recommand this game, more specifically to people who love platformers and strategy game. I don't regret anything about this purchase, a couple of nights (even days) of fun. Once again, GREAT GAME.

												Testing is probably the right thing to say about Portal 2, with all the puzzles in the game it is nearly impossible to get a grasp on all of them in an instant. But why doing all that brain-hurting stuff alone? Just take a friend with you - even if the story differs.But what makes Portal 2 this good? I played alot of it already and tested a lot of user created maps in the workshop, which is another great feature, they were really hard and i enjoyed to solve them alone or with friends even if you sometime get to a point where you are just frustrated because you just can't find the right way to do it.Anyway - Portal 2 is on of the best an funniest game i've ever played and so should you - have fun and good luck!

												EDIT FROM THE FUTURE:  Most of this is me being a nerdy scallop.  None of this is needed, but I still reccomend it nonetheless.Gosh... This game.  It'z amazing!  How have I not written a review for it yet?  Everything about it is fun.  I mean, you have a MASSIVE Singleplayer Campaign with a well thought out Story.  And you also have a Co-Op Campaign, with brilliant chamber design.  And even if you're done with the game, you can keep coming back for more with community made test chambers!  It's just so much bigger and better than the original Portal.  Speaking of how I feel about the original Portal... What did I rate it?  9.8 out of 10?  Well then, I say Portal 2 is a 23.6 out of 10!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												Portal 2 is an experience that must be played to truely understand what it is. Is it a shooter, or a puzzle game? The answer is both. Portal was one of the games that defined this generation of gaming, among other Valve creations, raising the bar for the quality of the sequel. I am happy to report that it does not dissapoint. With 3 new charactors (Wheatley, Cave Johnson and Caroline), Portal 2 delivers a plot that is perfect in nearly every way, adding to the original, but not taking away. Alongside the many charactor developments and plot twists that I will not mention (you have to see for yourself!), gameplay is beautiful. The added mechanics make for more interesting puzzles than in the first game and many more of said puzzles. The Aperture Science Handheld Portal Device, or the portal gun, is back and better than ever. You get the portal gun towards the start of the game and keep it until the end. You will encounter many new challenges that you must solve, up until the end. The end of the game is something that should not be spoiled, but I will tell you that it does not dissappoint.After the single-player experience, the game keeps going into the new co-op mode. Playing as one of two bots with your friend controlling the other makes for an interesting experience. Yes, this means there are two portal guns, and yes this means that there are four portals. These puzzles are challenging depending on how well you do. If you sit in the corner not contributing, you will not get through the first puzzle in the co-op campaign. There are many moments in co-op where you just feel like having fun and playing tricks on your partner, which the game lets you do. It is obvious that this game will put your friendship to the test. With voice chat and your "ping tool," you have ease of communication, so you can't blame the game for that. These tools are quite fun and easy to use, so there is no learning curve.To summerize, Portal 2 is definately worth the $20 it costs and even more worth it when it goes on sale. I've replayed the single-player many, many times and enjoyed the game all the way through my play time of 100+ hours. Portal 2 gets a 10/10.

												Expands on the original Portal formula adding some new tricks. Gameplay still remains similar to the original, although in the sequel, the campaign is certainly more of a full game. High production values make sure the game has excellent graphics and sound. Its got humour and at times feels like you're playing through a Pixar film. If you enjoyed the first Portal, the sequel is bigger and better, but if you didn't find the first game that special, I don't think the sequel will change your mind.

You now have to make your way through the abandoned ruins of Aperture with the Handheld Portal Device.Have fun with this game!

content:
Posted: October 15, 2014
												I have been playing this game for almost 11 years now, I got this game when it first released and it has come a long way since its first release. When it released, it was nothing but a racing game with only 2 cars in it, A Mini Cooper and a generic hatchback. Now today it is a puzzle game with portal guns and they are colourful and pretty. The switch from a racing game to a puzzle game was very good and I hardly noticed they switched. The puzzles in this game confuse me so much, I have yet to pass the second puzzle because I keep getting distracted by the beautiful visuals that are in this game. In the next update to this game I read online that they are adding a sniper rifle so we can shoot the turrets instead of being forced to use our brains to avoid them, which I think will add alot more variety in the game. My only wish is that they implement a Team Deathmatch style game mode where we can make classes and kill the other team. Overall, this game is a really good game that I rate 6 out of 10, get it.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 5, 2011
												Portal 2 takes the puzzle-solving formula of the original and expands upon it, whilst filling it out to make a full stand-alone game. There's a fantastic story well told with interesting characters and great set-pieces.The story is engaging, the sound design astounding (particularly the music), you'll want to push on to see the next twist in the plot, the next interaction with the games cast of off-beat characters. The voice acting and animation of these characters really bring some life to the corridors of Aperture Science.Some may be put off by the 'puzzle' element, and although that is a key part of the game, it's blended in so well you don't notice as the game changes foot from action to puzzles to story and back again; these elements each encroach upon each other, sometimes at unexpected moments. The game is well designed and balanced, unobtrusively teaching you all you need to progress, leaving you feeling like a genius.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 17, 2015
												This has got to be one of the most fun, most rewarding and entertaining experiences I have had in a game.First I simply played the single-player and enjoyed it a lot, felt I received my moneys worth. But after playing a bit of coop with my sister I just felt inspired to get around and write a review.So where to begin? Perhaps gameplay. It takes a gimmick, shooting portals to travel, manipulate stuff and ultimately solve puzzles. Portal 2 runs with the gimmick and, in true Valve-style, creates puzzles which feel more rewarding and organic than typical videogame puzzles, where it usually feels like you are trying to mind-read a cryptic all-powerful creature, a creature which tries its best to mask what it wants from you, which punishes every experimentation and failure harshly and without even giving you a clue of where you went wrong.Instead, Portal does things like Half-Life 2 did (I touched upon it in my HL2 review here), there´s more of a sense of observing, putting things together without too much arbitrary design choices and rules which never seem to stay consistent and trustworthy. Portal 1 and 2 has some arbitrary things like portals firing upon white surfaces, but it makes this clear and stick with this rule, it creates an environment where learning the rules is not useless, but you keep adding them up lawfully, like a scientist exploring how the game universe operates.It´s fun to figure puzzles out, rewarding, and you can incrementally add up the steps, instead of having to hold in mind a complicated maze and then have to succeed on your first try or start from scratch. I mean, you can and have to strategize, but it can be done in parts, and it is more organic, than feeling gamey, like having to remember the way to put some tilepuzzles together from some scrap of a picture you caught a glimpse of earlier in the game.The Single-Player story was fun, the pacing, telling, the little details you can pay attention to or run past are immersive. I could go on, but many of the strengths of Valve games are here in Portal 2, so what I´ve said about HL2 applies, in the style of relying on atmosphere, environments and observation, coupled with narration. It was a well rounded satisfying experience. I´ll admit it´s now some months since I played SP so I can´t go to more details, but my impression is still very positive. I still have a general idea of the actual substance of the story, it was a bit whacky at times, a scifi story with comedic twists and turns, but it was still told well and had the content was enjoyable, even Wheatley for me, though I´ve heard some were annoyed by that character.But the coop has been utterly fabulous. From the simple way to invite friends and jump into the game, the joy of figuring things out and the game giving the tools to allow you to communicate effectively (mic obviously a tool available), with pings with options to point out where to stand, what to look at, how to interact with, the remote view which allows you to see things from your friends perspective, and just the dynamic, organic humour of flying around portals, messing around, gesturing in a silly way, taunting Glados-- I haven´t played it yet fully, but I expect many more similarly enjoyable rich hours. There´s some story in there as well, it feels like Valve wanted the coop to be rich enough to stand equally strong on the SP campaign side. Some even like the coop more than SP, and I´m starting to see why.As a source engine, the game looks beautiful, plays solidly with little problems, bugs or performance issues, and is a great open engine allowing tweaks and mods. The game has Workshop and will possibly add even more fun to play, both SP and coop.If I were someone to give scores, my initial playthrough would have been a solid lovely 8-9/10, but now after starting to fool around with coop, this is simply 10+ out of ten for me.

content:
Posted: October 17, 2014
												Portal 2, what can I say, the game before it was brilliant but this one, this sequel, has just exeeded what everyone expected of it and more!Once again we are in aperture's science lab however things has changed since before (I won't give anything away about the storyline btw). There is a new robot to guide us and his name is Wheetley. He is absolutely briliant with is quick one-liners and has a fantastic voice actor just to rub it in. And once again there are a new set of mind-boggling puzzles to go through. The game has something that players who just got it will never see coming and the graphics are improved and look so much more immersive and beautiful than ever, you just can't go wrong with it. And like its previous game it has an absolutely amazing ending. However, unlike its previous game it no longer has a sense of the puzzles being repetitive and slightly to harsh for average brains and it is more focused on storyline too. It is definitly one of the best sequels to a game I have ever played and seen in my life.10/10Just play it, you won't be disapointed.

content:
Posted: January 4
												I'm going to tell you all a little story. A story of me, and my experiences with this amazing game.A few years back, I bought the game for my X-box 360. Unfortunatly, I bought Portal 2 before I bought the first one. I was fairly confused on a lot of things, but it didn't effect my experience much. This was before I had Steam, or even a computer, and I couldn't find the first one on disk. Anyways, Portal 2 quickly became my favourite game. I loved everything about it, and still do. I quickly finished the game, and moved on. Over the next few years, it still remained my favourite game. I spent a lot of time looking at all the easter eggs and references in the game. When I finally got a computer and Steam, I bought the first game, and loved it. Then i decided to buy Portal 2 for Steam, for a multitude of reasons. Mostly because it was on sale. As most puzzle games are, the game wasn't quite the same as the first time, but still remains my favourite. I pocked around in all the corners, looking for the easter eggs I'd seen online, and the game was almost as great as the first time. It was easier, as I knew what to do, but still absolutely amazing. So, I highly recommend this game. 1000/10. Go buy it. Play it. Have fun doing it. This game is hard not to enjoy. Evarything is great. the jokes, the puzzles, the characters. it still remains my favourite game to this day, and will likely stay that way, at least until Portal 3, or Half Life 3 is released. GabeN please make it. Plz

content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
												This could be the greatest game of all-time.A puzzle game, disguised as a first-person shooter, Portal 2 continues the story of the original Portal, and further builds on the chemistry between the silent protaganist (you) and the dry, witty yet homicidal A.I. controlling the facility you're trapped in.You start in a setting post-Portal, but wind up taking a tour of Aperture Science's past through a buried labyrinth of forgotten test chambers, as you learn the origins of the 'science' and GLaDOS.Stephen Merchant hilariously adds his talent to the voice cast as the bumbling Wheatley, and J. K. Simmons lends his stalwart, matter-of-fact tone to the newly introduced Cave Johnson, founder of Aperture.I can't imagine a more well-written or better voiced script.  You're guaranteed to love it!

												I must say this game is very well done. If I were to rate it, I would rate it 1,000,000,000/10! I really like how the game starts and how Wheatley helps you most of the way! My favourite part of Portal 2 is Co-Op becuase it gets more and more challenging!-------====================UPDATED 2016 EDITION====================-------Almost three years after buying this game on Steam, I still enjoy it SOOOOOOOO MUCH somehow, I have never EVER felt bored when playing this game and it has so many features and puzzles it's AWESOME!!! number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
												A truly well made 1st person puzzle platformer by valve.Portal (1) was a great little demo that got such a great reception they decided to make a follow up. Portal 2 is essentially the same as portal 1, but now a full AAA title, a bigger story, a fantastic well written antagonist, great humor and atmosphere. There are some new game play added, but the idea is still the same -  Get out of the (areas) by using the portal gun. Some puzzles are really quite clever.If you like the first portal, you must have this one too. Now it also has a co-op game and steam-workshop that ads a lot to the game, but the campaign alone is well worth the price of the admission.Even though the source engine might be a little dated, it still works absolutely perfect in this game. I never found myself thinking the game was old. What the games is trying to achieve, it does really well. It is quite a gloomy and sad place in a way, even though there is lots of clever and fun humor.I found myself coming back to the game at times, even though I have completed it. It just feels nice to complete again, and the antagonist(s) is(are) that good you don't mind hearing her(him) again.Runs well on most PCs and still manages to look great. I have no complains about this game. It is a very smooth experience. Runs better with mouse and keyboard even though it is quite well optimized for a controller.

No this is a game with many amizingly crazy wicked cracked eaten and puked out layers of deliciously goodness. Finding another game to play would be a pitty if this were not on you wishlist. I made this game, no i am not a watermelon in a tortilla? Where would you get that idea from anyway. Ok, let's talk characters. Glados, that is not how you spell the name BTW, yes you crazy guy who looks at the review. Dont think that the force is not strong with this game, oh f*ck is it ever. Your head will be spinning and you eyes will be soar after playing this awesome game. Oh, well yesterday i talked to obi wan kenobi, no he did not die. I asked him what game he wanted for christmas. He said Star Wa... I punched him in the eye, butt, nose, mouse, tooth, ear, and we we! Then he switched his awnser to Portal 2. Light sabers are no match for this mind boggling onion breath smelling thing of a game. We acually found a copy of this game while i was at the thrift shop, it was being sold for 100$. I asked why, the lady or maybe it was a man i am not too sure. But anyway, they said that that is their best selling item. Even though that was their only item and most expensive. Anyway, fighting yoda was hard if you are a noob at the force. and darth maul and wheatly. We tly we tea. ok well...

content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												When someone asks me what game they should buy with their $20 steam gift card they got for Father's Day, I say Portal 2. The crispy, warm, depressing, motivating, speed-running, beautiful game that is Portal 2. Anyone that own's ANY game playing platform, (obviously PC first, cause you know...master race.) should own Portal 2. This original is one in a million, wait, no. There are NO other games that come even close to this. Even the first Portal was like, "oh sweet I beat glados, that was fun." But Portal 2 is like, "OMG THAT ENDING WAS A.M.A.Z.I.N.G, Volvo please make something like this again, I'll pay 60 bucks easily." So, if that doesn't motivate you to pay, what $20? And it goes on sale during every freaking season for $3.99? It would be a mistake not to buy this game.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10, 2016
												Portal 2. This and the first Portal are games I've wanted to play for a while now. I got a laptop for Christmas this year, and I'm FINALLY able to play these two amazing games. The test chambers are challenging and the place you're in, (Aperture Science, which will always be better than Black Mesa :3) is BEAUTIFUL. This is a guy who doesn't care about graphics much, but good golly gravy is this game amazing looking. Not just that, but the voices for GLaDOS and Wheatley, Ellen McLain and Stephen Merchant, do an amazing job. Also, J.K. Simmons is amazing in this as Cave Johnson. That lemon speech is the funniest thing he says. Well, Wheatley really takes the cake for humor. And its not a lie. The writing for him is my favorite, and even when something happens that I won't spoil, he is hilarious. Only thing left for me to say is if you HAVEN'T played this game, play it if you can. It's something I think you'll enjoy. (Especially if you love robots)

												Pre-ordered this game back in 2010. Played both Portal 1 and 2. I spent over 400 hours on them. I can still play them at any time and I enjoy playing them. This game is genious and just proves that VALVe knows how to make games. Okay okay... Are you still thinking whether you should or should not buy this game? Okay, I'll help you.Do you like puzzle games?Yes: Buy Portal 2.No: Buy Portal 2.Oh.. you came becouse of an actual, useful review? Okay then...PLUSes+ Very good, somewhat gripping and super enjoyable story. Insane and unpredictable Plot Twists.+ Cooperation mode!+ Good graphics. Yet you can still somehow run this game on a toaster. Source Engine in a nutshell i guess.+ Gameplay is outstanding.+ Puzzles are not easy, yet not hard.MINUSes- Loadings. There are way too many of them...- Can't think of anything more really...Verdict: Buy it, there is no possible way you won't enjoy it. 9.99/10 bcoz nobody gives 10/10.
